content: The "Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2015" aims to address the issue of juveniles entering the criminal justice system for minor school infractions. Research shows that zero-tolerance policies lead to increased incarceration rates for juveniles, resulting in lower educational attainment, reduced earning potential, and higher likelihood of recidivism. The "Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2015" establishes the Office of School and Discipline Policy within the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention to reduce juvenile incarceration and criminal records resulting from school-related activities. The Office is tasked with collecting data on juvenile students' arrest and incarceration for school rule violations, promoting alternatives to detention, and studying the impact of school resource officers on arrest rates. The Office collects data on juvenile students' arrest and incarceration for school rule violations, aiming to reduce detention rates and analyze the influence of school resource officers on arrest rates. The School Discipline Policy Grant Program under SEC. 603 aims to reduce detention rates and analyze the impact of school resource officers on arrest rates. The Director may grant funds to States, local governments, and educational agencies to reduce juvenile arrests for school rule violations. Applicants demonstrating progress towards this goal will receive preference in grant awards. Students are arrested and incarcerated for violations of school rules or policies, as determined by the Director to further the purpose described in section 601(b). The text defines key terms such as 'school', 'school resource officer', 'local educational agency', and 'juvenile student'. It also authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2014 and 2015 to implement the provisions outlined in the title. Conditions for states to receive "COPS on the Beat" grants are outlined in Section 4. Section 1702(c) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include new requirements for states or local governments applying for grants related to juvenile justice administration. Juveniles who are arrested must receive adequate procedural due process, including timely notice, legal representation, and protections against self-incrimination. Juveniles arrested must have procedural due process, including notice, legal representation, protections against self-incrimination, and the right to cross-examine witnesses. Probation contracts for juveniles should not include clauses they cannot understand or lead to incarceration for school rule violations. The Attorney General is granted authority to access records related to juvenile justice under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. Additionally, a Department of Education grant program is established. The Secretary of Education will provide grants for training school personnel in de-escalation techniques to address student behavior issues and prevent law enforcement referrals. Eligible entities must submit an application demonstrating compliance with federal school discipline data reporting requirements. The Secretary of Education will provide grants for training school personnel in de-escalation techniques to address student behavior issues and prevent law enforcement referrals. Eligible entities must comply with federal school discipline data reporting requirements and may only receive assistance from one eligible entity during a grant period. The term "eligible entity" refers to a State, unit of general local government, or juvenile justice agency. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines terms related to school personnel. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2014 and 2015 to implement this section.
